title: InkLink
subtitle: Breaking writer's block through collaboration
summary: A chain-writing platform that reduces writer's block by turning writing into a shared, low-pressure activity where users contribute one passage at a time.

overview.title: Overview
overview.description:
Everyone has a story they never finished. Maybe it's a novel that stalled at chapter three. Maybe it's a screenplay that never made it past the outline. The ideas were there—the momentum wasn't.

InkLink started with a simple question: what if writing didn't have to be a solo activity? What if the pressure of finishing was replaced by the fun of contributing?

problem.title: The Problem
problem.description:
Writer's block isn't usually about running out of ideas. It's about pressure. The blank page. The expectation of perfection. The lonely weight of being solely responsible for what comes next.

We wanted to design an experience that removed those barriers—not by making writing easier, but by making it shared.

research.title: Research & Ideation
research.description:
We conducted peer surveys with amateur and hobbyist writers, usability testing on early concepts, and concept validation sessions to gauge interest.

Key findings: Most creative writing happens on desktop or tablet—not mobile phones. Dense, text-heavy layouts discourage reading and contribution. New concepts require gentle onboarding; users won't explore without guidance.

Our initial assumption was that mobile-first would work. Research quickly proved us wrong. Writers wanted screen real estate. They wanted to see the story unfold.

challenges.title: Early Challenges & Pivots
challenges.description: We made three major pivots based on user feedback and testing.

pivots.reason: Writers consistently preferred larger screens. Mobile felt cramped for both reading and contributing.
The newspaper aesthetic looked interesting but hurt readability. Hierarchy got lost in the visual noise.

pivots.from: Feature-heavy homepage with multiple entry points
pivots.reason: Users were overwhelmed by options. One clear path reduced hesitation.

lofi.title: Lo‑Fi Exploration
lofi.description:
Our lo-fi work focused on one core interaction: contributing to a story. We sketched different approaches to showing story history, handling turn-taking, and branching narratives. The visuals were intentionally basic—we needed to test logic, not aesthetics.

What emerged was a simple chain: read what came before, add your piece, pass it on.

iterations.title: High-Fidelity Designs
iterations.description: The high-fidelity designs leaned into typography and whitespace. We wanted the words to breathe. Color was used sparingly—mostly to indicate interactive elements and turn status. The writing itself stayed neutral, letting each contributor's voice come through without visual interference.
improvements: Highlighted CTAs for joining stories with motion and scale
Removed containers; visuals float in whitespace for editorial impact
Retuned animations for snappy ease-in/ease-out interactions
Progressive reveal interactions to guide users
Focused on typography and generous whitespace

solution.title: Final Solution
solution.description: InkLink has three core modes of engagement: Public Story Chains where anyone can contribute, Private Writing Circles for invite-only collaboration, and Timed Contributions that encourage momentum through optional deadlines.

features.title: Public Story Chains
features.description: Open stories that anyone can contribute to. Writers join, add a passage, and pass the story forward. Low barrier to entry—no commitment required.

features.title: Private Writing Circles
features.description: Invite-only spaces for friends or writing groups. Turn order is set by the creator. Offers control and familiarity.

features.title: Timed Contributions
features.description: Optional time limits encourage momentum. If a turn expires, the next writer can step in. Deadlines reduce overthinking.

validation.title: Validation & Testing
validation.description: Testers described InkLink as 'fun'—which felt like a win. The reduced pressure was noticeable. Users said they felt less precious about their contributions because they knew someone else would build on them. One tester mentioned that the time limit actually helped.

quotes.text: I stopped trying to make it perfect because I knew I only had a day.
quotes.author: Test participant

insights.title: Creativity benefits from constraints
insights.description: Limiting options (one clear CTA, timed turns) reduced friction instead of adding it.

insights.title: Visual clarity beats thematic styling
insights.description: The newspaper aesthetic was fun but counterproductive.

insights.title: Reducing features can increase engagement
insights.description: We cut more than we added—and the product got better.

nextSteps.title: Next Steps
items: Add saved drafts so writers can step away mid-contribution
Improve accessibility with keyboard navigation and screen reader support
Design better onboarding for first-time users unfamiliar with chain writing
